name: Vatha Kuzhambu
history: Vatha Kuzhambu is a traditional Tamil Nadu dish known for its tangy and spicy taste. It is a tamarind-based stew that typically features sun-dried vegetables like 'vathal' along with a variety of spices, embodying the essence of South Indian cuisine.
description: Vatha Kuzhambu is a flavorful South Indian gravy made with tamarind, sun-dried vegetables (vathal), and a special blend of spices. It's typically served with rice and is loved for its unique combination of sourness from the tamarind and heat from the spices.

instructions.title: Prepare Tamarind Water
instructions.description: Soak the tamarind paste in warm water, extract the juice, and set aside.

instructions.title: Fry the Vathal
instructions.description: Heat sesame oil in a pan. Add the mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, and asafoetida. Once the mustard seeds start to splutter, add the vathal and fry until golden.

instructions.title: Add Tamarind Water and Spices
instructions.description: Pour the tamarind water into the pan. Add sambar powder, curry leaves, and salt. Bring to a boil.

instructions.title: Simmer the Kuzhambu
instructions.description: Reduce the heat and let the kuzhambu simmer until it thickens to a gravy-like consistency.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Vatha Kuzhambu hot with steamed rice.

tips: Adjust the amount of sambar powder and red chilies to suit your taste.
Ensure the kuzhambu is simmered well for the flavors to meld together.
variations: You can add other vegetables like eggplant or okra to the kuzhambu.
For a different taste, use different types of vathal like sundakkai or manathakkali.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 3 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat on the stove over medium heat until warm.

presentationTips: Garnish with a few curry leaves for a fresh look.
Serve in a traditional clay pot for an authentic South Indian presentation.
